columns.text: In this problem, we will look at how the return on equity is affected by the company's growth rate that approaches the industry standard.

The return on equity of a company refers to the ratio of a company's net income and the equity of the shareholders. The return on equity of a company is a good measure of its profitability with a higher number being better. 

In the case of this problem, the company starts growth with a return on equity that is higher than everyone. However, we will assume that it started to slowly move towards the industry standard.

A constant payout ratio means that the percentage of earnings that is paid in dividends remain constant. From this, we can then conclude that the return on equity will start to decrease since the growth rate of the company is also decreasing and the payout ratio is no longer changing to compensate for the lower growth rate.

This means that investing in the company will become less profitable compared to when it started and when it has a higher growth rate.

textbook.authors: Bradford D. Jordan, Randolph W. Westerfield, Stephen A. Ross
